text: (upbeat music)
- Hey, hey, we are coming to you

from our hometown of Toronto!
- Yeah!

- Now, we just moved back
about a year and a half ago,

and we are ready to show
you all of the great things
that this city has to offer.

Since we've been
traveling for eight years,
we're a little out of touch
with what's going on in the city.
So we thought we'd better ask our friends

that have been here and
know the city really well,
what they think the best things to do
in Toronto are before we get started.

- So check out some of
the best things to do

here in Toronto from
Toronto's top travel bloggers.
(upbeat music)
- Hi, everyone, my name is Kristen Sarah

of Hopscotch the Globe,
and I am here to tell you
to check out The Poop Cafe in Toronto.
It is exactly what you think it is.
Or is it?

It is a cafe that serves
everything from meals to desserts
to beverages, and it all looks like poop.
It does not taste like poop, though!

When I was there, I had
a very delicious sundae.

A chocolate sundae, covered
in other chocolatey goodness,
served in a toilet bowl,
with a side latte served in a urinal,
while I sat on a toilet bowl,
and I was surrounded by poop emojis.

It was pretty much one of my
favorite days in Toronto, ever.

The fact that it says "Have
a nice poop" makes me smile.
I've wanted to go to Korea for years,
so I've done a lot of research on, like,
cool places to see and things to do.

And when I came across an
article on a poop cafe,
I was like, that's just the only reason
I need to go to Korea.
And I heard that they had one in Toronto,
I got so excited.

Here I am, about to experience
my first toilet ice cream.
If only my poop actually looked like this
when it landed in the toilet. (laughing)
It's so weird, but I love it.
Mm, I love the weird Korean culture.
(upbeat music)

- Hey, everyone, my name is
Arienne from Seeyousoon.ca,

and one of my favorite
things to do here in the city
is to visit the Toronto Islands.

Just a short ferry ride
from downtown Toronto

will take you to what
is collectively known
as the Toronto Islands.

Part residential and
part recreational space,
the Toronto Islands are North America's
largest car-free urban community.

It's very popular amongst
local Torontonians,
especially in the summer months.
There's lots to do here.

You can check out the
Gibraltar Point Lighthouse,
grab a bite to eat at the island cafe,

cycle the five and a half
kilometer bicycle trail
that spans the width of the islands,
visit Centreville Amusement Park,

and catch some rays at
one of the five beaches,

including a clothing-optional
beach at Hanlan's Point.

If you're here during the
winter, the Toronto Islands

also makes for a great visit
during the colder months.
Only the ferry to Wards Island
operates at this time of year,

but you'll be rewarded
with next to no crowds.

With its wide open
spaces and flat terrain,
outdoor activity lovers will enjoy
cross-country skiing or snowshoeing.
But no matter what time of year you visit,

be sure to pack your camera
because this is the best spot
to capture the Toronto skyline.
(upbeat music)
- Hey, guys, my name is Maiku,
and I'm an adventure filmmaker.

My favorite thing to do
while I'm here in Toronto,

and pretty much any other
city around the world, really,

is, you know when you're,
like, playing a video game,
you have your controller in your hand,

you push this button right
here, and it gives you

like an overview map of
your surrounding areas,
like a bird's eye view?

Well, the first thing I
like to do whenever I go

to a new city is I wanna
see that bird's eye view.
And before I go out and explore a city,
I like to book a helicopter
and get to see the bird's eye view.
So in Toronto, we have something called

the Toronto Heli Tour where
they have a helicopter
that will fly you around the CN Tower,
the SkyDome, Casa Loma, and it goes
generally all around the Toronto Islands,
it's a great way to get a big perspective
on what Toronto has to offer in general.
Toronto's a very, very big city.
Outside of the downtown court,
Toronto just kind of goes on forever.
And yeah, it's just something that I think

is super important in order
to give you that perspective,

give you that opportunity to
get those crazy photographs

that you want to show to
your friends and family

to show what kind of amazing
time you had in Toronto.

Now, if you want to go
off to Niagara Falls,
Niagara Falls has the same thing,
they have an amazing helicopter company

that flies over Niagara
Falls so you can get

that amazing shot to show
your friends and family,
and everyone on your Instagram channel,
what an amazing time you had here
while you were in Toronto.
(upbeat music)

- Hi, everyone, Lauren from
Justinpluslauren.com here.
I'm here at one of my favorite places
in Toronto, Graffiti Alley.

Technically, Graffiti
Alley is called Rush Lane,

and you'll find it just
south of Queen's Street West,
between Spadina and Portland.
There's colorful street art everywhere

covering every single wall,
tons of colorful murals.

One of the best things
about Graffiti Alley

is it's constantly changing,
every time you visit,

it'll be different from
one trip to the next.
So let's go take a look.
(upbeat music)
This is one of the best spots

where you definitely want to
get your shot for Instagram.
(upbeat music)

Popularized by Canadian
comedian Rick Mercer
as the site of his weekly rants,

Graffiti Alley attracts
tourists and locals alike.
(upbeat music)

If you're lucky, you may be
able to see an artist at work
to see how it all comes together.
(upbeat music)
- My name is Will from the YouTube channel

Going Awesome Places,
and if I had to pick,
my favorite spot in the city has to be

right here, Evergreen Brick
Works that opened in 2010,

this has truly been a
story of transformation,

starting off as a century-old
brick-making factory

which pretty much built
a lot of the bricks
that you see here in the city,

to this large-scale
environmental community space

that is leading in terms
of green technologies

and also just being an
awesome, vibrant public space.
Now, I come here for awesome hikes,

Saturday farmer's markets,
Sunday artisanal markets,
and special events like beer markets.
(upbeat music)

- Hey, everyone, I'm Kathryn
from Kathryn Anywhere.
Living in Toronto is absolutely amazing,

but sometimes this city can
really get under my skin.

It's noisy, it's loud,
it's cramped, it's crowded,

so I like to take out my
frustrations at The Rage Room.
(upbeat music)

When you go to The Rage
Room, they give you
this whole suit of protective gear.

They give you weapons like
crowbars and baseball bats,
they give you glass you can break,
you can bring your own garbage,
you can just smash it and break it,
and you don't have to clean any of it up.
You leave it all for them, win-win.

Go online to battlesports.ca
for $45 for 45 minutes.

For one person, you
get the protective gear

and items that you can smash
and let out your frustrations.

You can also do this
as a date night package

for two people, or you can
totally do a super smash party
for four people in the room at once.

Get out your frustrations,
break some stuff,
and don't worry about the cleanup.
That's The Rage Room in Toronto,
and that's my son, who's hungry.
(upbeat music)

Hey, guys, it's your
boy Christopher Rudder
from the travel blog Rudderless Travel.

One of my favorite things
to do here in Toronto

is toss some axes around over
at Batl Axe, check it out.

With over 10.8 million axes
thrown at Batl Axe locations

in 2018, Batl Axe offers
expert axe-throwing coaches,

private lanes, and facilities
with food and drink,

which includes beer, for
people of all abilities

to compete and have fun,
and I gotta tell ya,
this place is an absolute blast.

My aim, impeccable, but I had
difficulties making it stick.
With nine locations in Ontario,
three of those right here in Toronto,

trust me, it's perfect
for birthday parties,
team-building, corporate parties,

bachelorette parties,
bachelor parties, et cetera.

So come on down and
let off a little steam.

(axe thuds)
(people cheering)
(elegant music)
- Hi, I'm Yashy from Baby and Life,
and living in downtown Toronto,
we take solace at the Royal Ontario Museum
when we're looking to escape
the cold winters and the summer heat.
The ROM is Canada's largest museum,

and it attracts over a
million visitors per year,

which makes it also Canada's
most visited museum.
Inside this uniquely-shaped building,

you will find life-size
dinosaur recreations,

and interactive displays
to get your learning on.
(elegant music)

Now, I have kids, so that means
that I spend most of my time

digging for dinosaur
bones and playing dress-up

with the ancient garments
and dresses here.
However, with 40 permanent galleries
and additional interactive exhibitions,

there's plenty to do
between the four floors
that make up the ROM.

A personal favorite is the
Earth's Treasures Gallery.
With nearly 3,000 pieces in here,

walking through this space
is like walking through
the most prestigious jewelry store.

And remember, on the third
Monday of each month,

you can enjoy free admission
to the ROM every evening.
(elegant music)
(upbeat music)

- Hi, I'm Nora Dunn,
and I'm otherwise known
as the professional hobo.

I may have traveled the
world full-time for 12 years,

but Toronto is my hometown,
born and raised in Toronto.
One of my favorite things to do in Toronto
is to visit the Ontario Science Centre.
There's something for everybody.
Kids and adults alike will have the chance
to get hands-on with a variety of exhibits

and experiments and different
ways to enjoy science.

And I'm not particularly
a scientific girl,

but let me tell you, I enjoyed
spending many of my weekends
at the Toronto Science Centre.
(upbeat music)
Hey, there, this is Kevin

from Wandering Wagars
Adventure Family Travel.

One of my favorite places
to visit in Toronto
is the Ripley's Aquarium of Canada.
(upbeat music)
This immersive exhibit houses over 20,000
aquatic animals, from shrimp to sharks.
Ripley's Aquarium is a perfect destination
for families, couples, pretty much anyone
who wants to enjoy the underwater world
without strapping on a snorkel.

At the aquarium, you can
get up close and personal

with horseshoe crabs,
jellyfish, and so much more.
You can even walk the longest underwater
viewing tunnel in North America.
(upbeat music)
- I'm Christopher Rudder
from the travel blog Rudderless Travel.
- And I'm Kathryn from Kathryn Anywhere.
I'm here in Kensington Market

because this is one of my
favorite places in Toronto.
We can't wait to show you around.

One of the reasons that
we love Kensington Market

is for the coffee shops,
the craft breweries--

- [Kathryn] The amazing

from all over the world,
and thrift shopping.

It's such an eclectic
place, everything's unique.
There's no doubles of everything.
There's just one of everything,

and they do whatever
they do amazingly well.

Hey, everybody, we're here

1.5 million people visit
the CN Tower each year,
but only a handful try The EdgeWalk.
It's the world's highest skywalk,
and one of Toronto's greatest adventures.
The CN Tower itself is 553 metres high,

and it is the tallest
free-standing structure
in the Western Hemisphere.
The EdgeWalk took us to the 116th floor

at 356 metres above Toronto,
where we had the chance
to walk around the circumference
while taking in the amazing views.
(upbeat music)
